name: Roti
history: Roti, also known as Chapati, is a staple in Indian cuisine and is enjoyed in various forms across the country. This unleavened bread has its origins in the Indian subcontinent and is known for its simplicity and versatility.
description: Roti is a flatbread made from whole wheat flour, known for its soft texture and smoky flavor. It's typically cooked on a flat griddle and is served with a variety of dishes, ranging from curries to dry vegetables.

instructions.title: Make the Dough
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, combine whole wheat flour and salt. Gradually add water and knead to form a smooth and soft dough. Cover and let it rest for 15 minutes.

instructions.title: Roll the Rotis
instructions.description: Divide the dough into small balls. Using a rolling pin, roll each ball into a thin, flat circle.

instructions.title: Cook the Rotis
instructions.description: Heat a tawa or griddle over medium heat. Place the rolled-out dough onto the tawa. Cook until small bubbles appear, then flip. Cook the other side until brown spots appear. Optionally, finish cooking over an open flame for a smoky flavor.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the rotis hot, optionally brushed with ghee or oil. Pair with your favorite curry, dal, or vegetable dish.

tips: Ensure the dough is soft and pliable for soft rotis.
Do not overcook, as rotis can become hard and chewy.
variations: Add carom seeds (ajwain) or cumin seeds for added flavor.
Mix in spinach puree or grated vegetables for a nutritional boost.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh. Can be stored in an airtight container for up to 1 day.
storage.instructions: Reheat on the griddle before serving if stored.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat on a tawa or griddle until warm and soft.

presentationTips: Serve in a basket lined with a cloth to keep them warm.
Arrange in a stack for an appealing presentation.
